A newer, better vintage fair?

19/03/2011

York Does Vintage is a new alternative to the usual student haunt, Judy's Vintage Fair. Hannah Clugston checks out the new competitor, and likes what she sees

Image by

By James Bithell

When: 5th March Where: York Does Vintage, St William's College York Souk, Fashion and Lifestyle Bazaar, Park Inn Hotel Walking through the archway at St William's College into the cobblestone courtyard it is easy to see why York is a prime spot for a vintage fair. It makes sense really, the buildings hark back to a lost time when craftsmanship and beauty was more important than money, and we see the same care in vintage clothes. Alex Claydon, the York St John graduate who decided to set up York Does Vintage was drawn into vintage after her Great Aunt died and left behind a whole wardrobe of beautiful items. Soon after she set up Audrey & Joans, an online store featuring hand picked vintage items. "York has a massive vintage scene to be undiscovered" Claydon comments, "so a York based fair is ideal". Indeed, as I floated from stall to stall chatting to the stall tenders it became apparent that the majority of them were either from York or Yorkshire in general. Perhaps it was the locality of the companies or the smaller size of the room but York Does Vintage felt a lot more personal than the usual Judy's Vintage Fair. It was set up to encourage interaction, with the tenders sat at tables rather than looming in the corner of a clothes rail. It was also a much more comfortable experience: the level of commitment that the tenders had put into the decoration of their stalls made you feel as though you'd walked into someone's living room. What Claydon really appeared to be doing with her fair was treating her customers to a vintage experience. After leisurely picking and choosing clothes from what felt like someone's living room, you could head over to the hairdressers stall and see what you'd really look like with a retro hairstyle or grab a tea and a scone at the Curiositea Stall. The rest of the stalls covered anything from sweets to furniture. Part of the beauty of the experience was being able to meet the passionate stall owners, who talked about making the decision to "go vintage". Rachel Sanchez, running Violet Wilde, a York based lingerie company, explained her move from company work to her own business: "The company didn't give me any room to make what I liked so I decided to become self employed". The burlesque-inspired corsets Sanchez designs boast the intrinsic crafting of a Victorian corset whilst using bold patterned material to give them a modern twist. Ky Wheeler, the owner and creator of Razor Blade Mermaid Jewellery moved to working vintage fairs after her job got too stressful, now only working part time. Her collection of pieces combined sophistication with fairy tales, leaving me wide-eyed attempting to take in all the beads, buttons and colours in one take. Wheeler attributed her inspiration to "horror, alternative fashion and rock and rockabilly". Something that can often be neglected at vintage fairs is the acknowledgement of the modern vintage. Vintage is not a redundant form only found in old closets but, as is evident with Sanchez and Wheeler, is a style of clothing that can be recreated over and over again. Claydon masterfully set up her fair to hold both new and old, with 1920's stalls such as House of Avalon and Nancy's to sit opposite creations formed last week. And my Saturday morning fashion trip seemed to follow a similar pattern: on leaving vintage behind in the older side of York I tripped over the Ouse into the relatively modern Park Hill Hotel to discover a forward looking fashion fair. Souk was almost the antithesis of York Does Vintage as it promoted the designers of the future. It was clear from meeting Sam Agnew, the organiser of Souk, that the day was intended to open up new doors in fashion and involve York in that experience: "There were no fairs in York along the fashion genre so I decided to organise one myself". Agnew owns her own jewellery company and understands the need to give self-owned companies a platform to promote their own fashion vision. What tied Souk and York Does Vintage together so neatly was the way one looked back whilst the other looked forward, exhibiting a whole breadth of the fashion world in one day. But there was still a sense of respect for fashion roots at Souk. The first designer I met, Bo Carter, described her designs as Victorian punk and this clash of genres results in bold patterns and tailored shapes. In looking back she was able to create something completely new. But there was also respect for old material and Agnew had employed several ethical boutiques to promote "up-cycling". Antiform, a company from Leeds re-use old material to create anything from dresses to handbags. The dresses were not cheap, but as the owner noted, they are one of the most ethical ways to shop because you are reducing the mass of clothes already out there. Agnew had even set up stalls for customers to experiment creating their own products, "I want people to see what they can do with the clothes they already own." A concerning factor for me recently has been the fact that in generations to come our grandchildren will not be able to delve into our wardrobes and enjoy past decades because all our cheaply made clothes will of disintegrated. But seeing Souk next to York Does Vintage helped me to see a way out of this problem. If we buy from designers with handmade clothes from places like Souk in years to come people will still be able to enjoy vintage in York. Souk and York Does Vintage will return together in Week 3 (May 14th-15th) for a bigger weekend event
